messages.content: I don't think loops are valid operations within any circuits so you would have to assert each case individually. I can be wrong though fyi

So in your case you would have to do 
arr[0].assert
arr[1].assert and so on
Actually you can use a loop as long as it’s a constant size!
The main thing is that when you compile the circuit, you must know the number of steps required.
ohhh, can you share an example???

What gets you into trouble is if you want to write an exponentiation circuit that does the same loop but uses a dynamic input.  The same circuit can't loop 3, 4, 5, or more times depending on the input, but you _can_ use a loop as long as it will always produce the same steps.

It's a tricky rule to follow, so be careful 🙂
By "The same circuit can't loop 3, 4, 5, or more times depending on the input" do you mean like if in your example the `2` in your `i < 2` for loop condition was a dynamic input?
But it should work if I explicitly always have an array of say 10/100 elements yeah?

note that because you can't turn field elements into values, i.e. `n.toString()` throws an error, it's almost impossible to _accidentally_ write dynamically sized loops, or branch on the value of field elements
so not that tricky to follow IMO, just don't turn field elements into values 😄

This seems to be a recurring misunderstanding. I tried to address it here as well: 

https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/faq#does-o1js-compile-my-javascript-code-to-an-arithmetic-circuit
> It's fine to use if-statements, for-loops, arrays, objects, and any other JavaScript language constructs to facilitate writing circuits. However, be aware that these flexible constructs don't allow you to overcome the static nature of circuits.

@Düldül Osman I find it funny that you ask whether to unroll the JS loop (i.e. write it out explicitly) so that it becomes valid.

It's funny because there is absolutely no way this can change anything. The for-loop and its unrolled version are pieces of JS that behave in exactly the same way. And there's nothing magical happening in o1js that could make them different.
yes, but I don't know exactly what zkprogram does when it is compiled, and I'm not sure how it evaluates for loops. I think it was a question mark in the minds of many people like me in here.

I think the misunderstanding comes from comparing o1js with custom DSLs where your code is transformed (compiled) into something else before becoming a circuit. But o1js doesn't work like that, it's just JS!
